articles.headline: Brazil on Edge as World Cup Exposes Rifts
articles.snippet: While some Brazilians are excited that their country is hosting the World Cup, others resent the event’s ballooning costs and a sluggish post-boom economy.
articles.abstract: While some Brazilians are excited that their country is hosting the World Cup, others resent the event’s ballooning costs and a sluggish post-boom economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s list of feats since ending authoritarian rule in the 1980s is as long as it is varied, including antipoverty programs pulling millions into the middle class, the democratic election of presidents who suffered indignities under the dictatorship and the surging growth of tropical agriculture to help feed the world.

articles.headline: G.M. Suits Will Proceed as One Case in New York
articles.snippet: The consolidation of more than 80 lawsuits against General Motors into a single proceeding in Manhattan represents a small but meaningful victory for the automaker.
articles.abstract: The consolidation of more than 80 lawsuits against General Motors into a single proceeding in Manhattan represents a small but meaningful victory for the automaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: A panel of federal judges handed General Motors a modest but meaningful victory on Monday, consolidating the pretrial phase of more than 80 lawsuits against the company into a single proceeding in Manhattan — the venue sought by the automaker.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: 2nd China Army Unit Implicated in Online Spying
articles.snippet: A report by CrowdStrike, a security company, ties a hacker group in Shanghai to attacks on governments, contractors and research companies.
articles.abstract: A report by CrowdStrike, a security company, ties a hacker group in Shanghai to attacks on governments, contractors and research companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The email attachment looked like a brochure for a yoga studio in Toulouse, France, the center of the European aerospace industry. But once it was opened, it allowed hackers to sidestep their victim’s network security and steal closely guarded satellite technology.

articles.headline: Competition Is Stiff to Manage Tech Billions
articles.snippet: Wealthy entrepreneurs represent a potential gold mine for financial advisers.
articles.abstract: Wealthy entrepreneurs represent a potential gold mine for financial advisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Microsoft went public in 1986, its chief executive and largest shareholder, Bill Gates, wound up with a broker at Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street firm that had led the company’s initial public offering.

articles.headline: Why Uber Might Well Be Worth $18 Billion
articles.snippet: Though some call the taxi app’s valuation of $18.2 billion “insane,” it’s worth doing the basic math and taking a closer look.
articles.abstract: Though some call the taxi app’s valuation of $18.2 billion “insane,” it’s worth doing the basic math and taking a closer look.

articles.headline: For Western Oil Companies, Expanding in Russia Is a Dance Around Sanctions
articles.snippet: BP, Exxon Mobil, Shell, Total and other big Western oil companies are striking deals and plowing money into Russia even as more sanctions loom.
articles.abstract: BP, Exxon Mobil, Shell, Total and other big Western oil companies are striking deals and plowing money into Russia even as more sanctions loom.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Like many chief executives of American companies, Rex W. Tillerson of Exxon Mobil didn’t attend the major business forum in Russia last month, at the urging of White House officials. But the company’s exploration chief, Neil W. Duffin, did.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Democrats See Winning Issue in Carbon Plan
articles.snippet: Several Democrats in competitive Senate races have supported an E.P.A. proposal to curb power-plant emissions, citing growing public support for action and perceptions that Republicans are anti-science.
articles.abstract: Several Democrats in competitive Senate races have supported an E.P.A. proposal to curb power-plant emissions, citing growing public support for action and perceptions that Republicans are anti-science.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is a Democrat in a marquee Senate race, pressed by a strong Republican in a state with a challenging political environment. So when a new proposal to limit power plant emissions was seen as posing a threat to allies of the Obama administration, Senator Mark Udall of Colorado acted quickly: He embraced the plan.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Colleges and Evangelicals Collide on Bias Policy
articles.snippet: The Bowdoin Christian Fellowship group will cease to be recognized on campus after refusing to adhere to rules barring discrimination based on a person’s religious beliefs.
articles.abstract: The Bowdoin Christian Fellowship group will cease to be recognized on campus after refusing to adhere to rules barring discrimination based on a person’s religious beliefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUNSWICK, Me. — For 40 years, evangelicals at Bowdoin College have gathered periodically to study the Bible together, to pray and to worship. They are a tiny minority on the liberal arts college campus, but they have been a part of the school’s community, gathering in the chapel, the dining center, the dorms.

articles.headline: Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
articles.snippet: Militants spilling over the border from Syria seized control of Iraq’s second-largest city in the most stunning success yet of a rapidly widening insurgency that threatens to drag the region into war.
articles.abstract: Militants spilling over the border from Syria seized control of Iraq’s second-largest city in the most stunning success yet of a rapidly widening insurgency that threatens to drag the region into war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants spilling over the border from Syria on Tuesday seized control of the northern city of Mosul, Iraq’s second largest, in the most stunning success yet in a rapidly widening insurgency that threatens to drag the region into war.
articles.byline: By Suadad Al-Salhy and Tim Arango
